Authors: Cathy L Cripps, Ellen Larsson, Jukka Vauras
Title:
Nodulose-spored Inocybe species (Cortinatae, Marginatae) from
the Rocky Mountain alpine zone: molecularly linked to European and type
specimens
Keywords:
Arctic-alpine, biogeography, Colorado, Inocybaceae, J.
Favre, molecular systematics, Montana, Salix, taxonomy, type
collections, new species
Abstract:
Inocybe (Inocybaceae) is one of the most diverse
ectomycorrhizal genera in Arctic and alpine habitats where primary hosts
are Salix, Betula and Dryas. Subgenus Inocybe is common in these
habitats and is characterized by the presence of thick-walled
pleurocystidia; here we focus on species in this section that have
angular or nodulose spores. Historically, over thirty taxa from this
group have been reported from Arctic and alpine habitats. Many have been
synonymized, while molecular analysis has revealed new species. The nuc
rDNA ITS1-5.8S-ITS2 (internal transcribed spacer [ITS] barcode) sequence
data of twenty-four type specimens in this group now allows for further
taxonomic clarification and comparison across continents of disjunct
populations. Here we compare sequence data of the ITS and about 1200bp
of the 5´end of nuc 28S rDNA [LSU] from Rocky Mountain specimens with
those of types and European reference material. We report ten species
from the Rocky Mountain alpine zone, of which five are conspecific with
known European boreal or alpine species, and four are described as new;
all have intercontinental distributions except I. neolemmi.
Nodulose-spored Inocybes that occur in the Rocky Mountain alpine zone
include: Inocybe alpinomarginata sp. nov., I. arctica, I. giacomi, I.
cf. giacomi, I. murina sp. nov., I. neolemmi sp. nov., I. occulta, I.
paragicomi sp. nov., I. phaeocystidiosa, and I. purpureobadia.
Remarkably, in the Rocky Mountains these species occur at elevations up
to 4000 m and at latitudes as low as 360 N, hundreds of miles from the
Arctic, the European alpine, and original type localities. Distributions
are explained in part by host distributions and glaciation. A key and
full descriptions for Rocky mountain species are provided to promote
species recognition.
